fr:mainmatter.fr:p: If \Gamma _{p} is a nonempty finite set of propositional formulas and \phi _p is a propositional formula, then \phi _p is a propositional consequence of \Gamma _{p} if and only if [\gamma _{1p} \land \cdots \land \gamma _{np}] \to \phi _p is a tautology.

Suppose that \phi _p is a propositional consequence of \Gamma _p. Let v be any truth assignment. Suppose v makes the formula [\gamma _{1p} \land \cdots \land \gamma _{np}] false. Then, [\gamma _{1p} \land \cdots \land \gamma _{np}] \to \phi _p is true. Suppose v makes the formula [\gamma _{1p} \land \cdots \land \gamma _{np}] true. By definition, v makes \phi _p true. Then, [\gamma _{1p} \land \cdots \land \gamma _{np}] \to \phi _p is true. So the formula is a tautology.

Suppose that [\gamma _{1p} \land \cdots \land \gamma _{np}] \to \phi _p is a tautology. Let v be a truth assignment such that \overline (v)([\gamma _{1p} \land \cdots \land \gamma _{np}]) = T. If there is no such assignment, then the claim holds vacuosly. We know that \overline (v)(\phi _p) = T by definiton of tautology. Thus, every assignment that makes the formulas in \Gamma _p true also makes \phi _p true. Thus, \phi _p is a propositional consequence of \Gamma _p.
These are notes from a Mathematical Logic class taught by Alexander Van Abel at Wesleyan University. Any mistakes in the following material are my own.

A first-order language \mathcal {L} is an infinite collection of distinct symbols, where no symbol is contained in another, in the following categories:
The following are logical symbols that belong to every language:
"(", ")"
"\lor ", "\lnot "
"\forall "
"v_1," "v_{2}", ... (an infinite sequence of variables). The set of variables is denoted Vars.
"="
The following are non-logical symbols that a language is not required to contain
Constant symbols.
For every n, n-ary function symbols.
For every n, n-ary relation symbols.

If \mathcal {L} is a language a term of \mathcal {L} is a nonempty finite string t of symbols from \mathcal {L} such that either:
t is a constant symbol
t is a variable
t \coloneq f t_{1} t_{2} \cdots t_{n}, , where f is an n-ary function symbol of \mathcal {L} and each of the t_i is a term of \mathcal {L}
The set of terms of \mathcal {L} is the smallest set of strings that adhere to the preceding properties.
The symbol \coloneq is not a part of \mathcal {L}, but a meta-linguistic symbol that means the strings of \mathcal {L}-symbols on each side of the \coloneq are identical.
The set of formulas of \mathcal {L} is the smallest set of strings that adhere to the preceding properties.

The language \mathcal {L}_{NT} is \{0, S, +, \cdot , E, <\} , where 0 is a constant symbol, S is a unary function symbol, +, \cdot , and E are binary function symbols, and < is a binary relation symbol. This will be referred to as the language of number theory.

Suppose that v is a variable and \phi is a formula. We will say that v is free in \phi if
\phi is atomic and v and occurs in \phi
\phi :\equiv (\lnot \alpha ) and v is free in \alpha
\phi :\equiv (\alpha \lor \beta ) and v is free in at least one of \alpha or \beta
\phi :\equiv (\forall u)(\alpha ) and v is not u and v is free \alpha

For example, consider \mathcal {N} = (\mathbb {N}, 0, S, +, \cdot , E, <), where we ignore the superscripts for the constants, functions, and relations and everything else gets its standard interpretation. This structure is called the standard \mathcal {L}^{NT}-structure.

If \mathcal {U} is an \mathcal {L}-structure, a variable assignment function into \mathcal {U} is a function s that assigns to each variable an element of the universe A. Thus, s can be any function with type s : Vars \to A
Suppose s is a variable assignment function into \mathcal {U}. Then,

fr:resource.fr:resource-source: $ s[x|a] = \begin {cases} s(v) & \text { if } v \neq x \\ a & v = x \end {cases}$

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: We call the function s[x|a] an x-modification of the assignment function s.

Suppose that \mathcal {U} is an \mathcal {L}-structure with the variable assignment s. The function \overline {s} : \mathcal {L}-terms \to A is defined inductively as follows:
t :\equiv v, then \overline {s}(t) = s(t)
t :\equiv c, then \overline {s} (t) = c^{\mathcal {U}}
t :\equiv f t_{1} \cdots t_{n}, then \overline {s}(t) = f^{\mathcal {U}}(\overline {s}(t_{1}), \cdots , \overline {s}(t_{n}))

Suppose that \mathcal {U} is a \mathcal {L}-structure, \phi is an \mathcal {L}-formula and s : Vars \to A is an assignment function. The satisfies relation, denoted \mathcal {U} \vDash \phi [s], is inductively defined as follows:
\mathcal {U} \vDash = t_{1}t_{2}[s] iff \overline {s}(t_1) = \overline {s}(t_2)
\mathcal {U} \vDash R t_1 \cdots t_n[s] iff (\overline {s}(t_1) \cdots \overline {s}(t_n)) \in R^{\mathcal {U}}
\mathcal {U} \vDash (\lnot \alpha )[s] iff \mathcal {U} \nvDash \alpha [s]
\mathcal {U} \vDash (\alpha \lor \beta )[s] iff \mathcal {U} \vDash \alpha [s] or \mathcal {U} \vDash \beta [s]
\mathcal {U} \vDash (\forall x)(\alpha ) iff for each a \in A, \mathcal {U} \vDash \alpha [s(x/a)]
Suppose that s_1 and s_2 are variable assignment functions into a structure \mathcal {U} such that s_1(v) = s_2(v) for every variable v in the term t. Then, \overline {s_1}(v) = \overline {s_2}(v).

As a corollary: If \sigma is a sentence in the language \mathcal {L} and \mathcal {U} is an \mathcal {L}-structure, either \mathcal {U} \vDash \sigma [s] for all assignment functions s, or \mathcal {U} \vdash \sigma [s] for no assignment function s.

If \phi is a formula in the language \mathcal {L} and \mathcal {U} is an \mathcal {L}-structure, \mathcal {U} is a model of \phi , denoted \mathcal {U} \vDash \phi , if and only if \mathcal {U} \vDash \phi [s] for every assignment function s.
If \Phi is a set of \mathcal {L} formulas, then \mathcal {U} \vDash \Phi if and only if \mathcal {U} \vdash \phi for each \phi \in \Phi .

Suppose that u is a term, x is a variable, and t is a term. The term u^{x}_{t} is inductively defined as follows:
u, u :\nequiv x
t, u :\equiv x
u, u :\equiv c, where c is some constant symbol
f(u_1)^{x}_{t}(u_2)^{x}_{t} \cdots (u_n)^{x}_{t}, u :\equiv f u_{1} \cdots u_{n}

Suppose that \phi is an \mathcal {L}-formula, t is a term, and x is a variable. The formula \phi ^{x}_{t} is inductively defined as follows:
= (u_1)^{x}_{t} (u_2)^{x}_{t} , \phi :\equiv = u_1 u_2
R (u_1)^{x}_{t} \cdots (u_2)^{x}_{t} , \phi :\equiv R u_1 \cdots u_n
\lnot (\alpha )^{x}_{t}, \phi :\equiv \lnot (\alpha )
( \alpha ^{x}_{t} \lor \beta ^{x}_{t}), \phi :\equiv \alpha \lor \beta
\phi if x :\equiv y and (\forall y)(\alpha ^{x}_{t}) otherwise, \phi :\equiv (\forall y)(\alpha )

Suppose that \Delta and \Gamma are sets of \mathcal {L}-formulas. We will say that \Delta logically implies \Gamma and write \Delta \vDash \Gamma if for every \mathcal {L}-structure \mathcal {U}, if \mathcal {U} \vDash \Delta , then \mathcal {U} \vDash \Gamma .

An \mathcal {L}-formula \phi is valid if \empty \vDash \phi , meaning if \phi is true in every \mathcal {L}-structure with every assignment function s. We write \vDash \phi to denote that \phi is valid.

Suppose that \phi is an L-formula, t is a term and x is a variable. We say that t is substitutable for x in \phi if
\phi is atomic
\phi :\equiv \lnot (\alpha ) and t is substitutable for x in \alpha
\phi :\equiv (\alpha \lor \beta ) and t is substitutable for x in both \alpha and \beta
\phi :\equiv (\forall y)(\alpha ) and either x is not free in \phi or y does not occur in t and t is substitutable for x in \alpha

Suppose that \Sigma is a collection of \mathcal {L}-formulas and D is a finite sequence (\phi _{1}, \cdots , \phi _{n}) of \mathcal {L}-formulas. We say that D is a deduction from \Sigma if for each i, 1 \leq i \leq n, either
\phi _{i} \in \Lambda
\phi _i \in \Sigma
There is a rule of inference (\Gamma , \phi _i) such that \Gamma \subset \{\phi _1, \cdots , \phi _n\}
If there is a deduction from \Sigma with \phi as the last line, we call this a deduction from \Sigma of \phi , and write \Sigma \vdash \phi .

Fix sets of \mathcal {L}-formulas \Sigma and \Lambda and a collection of rules of inference. The set T = \{ \phi | \Sigma \vdash \phi \} is the smallest set C such that
\Sigma \subset C
\Lambda \subset C
If (\Gamma , \theta ) is a rule of inference and \Gamma \subset C, then \theta \in C

We begin by proving the three properties for T.
We want to show that \Sigma \subset T. It is sufficient to show that each \sigma \in \Sigma is in T. Well, for each \sigma \in \Sigma we know that \Sigma \vdash \sigma because we can write the one line deduction with just \sigma . Thus, \sigma \in \Sigma is in T.

We want to show that \Lambda \subset T. It is sufficient to show that each \lambda \in \Lambda is in T. Well, for each \lambda in \Lambda we know that \Sigma \vdash \lambda because we can write the one line deduction with just \lambda . Thus. \lambda in \Lambda is in T.

Suppose that (\Gamma , \theta ) is a rule of inference and that \Gamma \subset T. We want to show that \theta \in T. It is sufficient to create a deduction from \Sigma that ends with \theta . By our supposition that \Gamma \subset T, we know that each \gamma \in T. Thus, \Sigma \vdash \gamma for each \gamma . Consider the deduction that is the concatenation of all the deductions ending in a \gamma . From this deduction, we can add the line \theta because \Gamma is a subset of the preceding lines. Thus, we have constructed a deduction from \Sigma to \theta .

Now, we want to show that T is the smallest such set that satisfies the aforementioned properties. Consider a set C that satisfies the three properties. It is sufficient to show that T \subset C by demonstrating that all \phi \in T are also in C. Let \phi \in T. There must be deduction from \Sigma to \phi . Suppose that the last line \phi is justified because it is a logical or non-logical axiom. Then, \phi is in C by definition. Now suppose that \phi is justified by a rule of inference. Then, there is a (\Gamma , \phi ) such that each \gamma appears deduction. Thus, by straightforward induction we get each \gamma is in C. Thus, by the third property, \phi is in C.

The groups of quanitfier axioms are defined as follows:
(\forall x. \phi ) \rightarrow \phi ^{x}_{t} if t is substitutable for x in \phi
\phi ^{x}_{t} \to (\exists x \phi ), if t is substitutable for x in \phi

Given an assignment v : Vars \to \{T, F\} we extend v to \overline {v} as follows:
v(\phi ) if \phi is a propositional variable
F if \phi :\equiv (\lnot \alpha ) and \overline (v)(\alpha ) = T
F if \phi :\equiv (\alpha \lor \beta ) and \overline (v)(\alpha ) = \overline (v)(\beta ) = F
T otherwise

Suppose that \Gamma _{p} is a set of propositional formulas and \phi _{p} is a propositional formula. We say that \phi _{p} is a propositional consequence of \Gamma _{p} if every truth assignment that makes each formula in \Gamma _{p} true also makes \phi _{p} true. Notice \phi _{p} is a tautology if \phi _p is a propositional consequence of \empty .

We also overload this terminology to sets of \mathcal {L}-formulas \Gamma and \mathcal {L}-formulas \phi to indicate that \phi is a propositional consequence of \Gamma after both undergo the transformation to propositional formulas.

If \Gamma _{p} is a nonempty finite set of propositional formulas and \phi _p is a propositional formula, then \phi _p is a propositional consequence of \Gamma _{p} if and only if [\gamma _{1p} \land \cdots \land \gamma _{np}] \to \phi _p is a tautology.

Suppose that \phi _p is a propositional consequence of \Gamma _p. Let v be any truth assignment. Suppose v makes the formula [\gamma _{1p} \land \cdots \land \gamma _{np}] false. Then, [\gamma _{1p} \land \cdots \land \gamma _{np}] \to \phi _p is true. Suppose v makes the formula [\gamma _{1p} \land \cdots \land \gamma _{np}] true. By definition, v makes \phi _p true. Then, [\gamma _{1p} \land \cdots \land \gamma _{np}] \to \phi _p is true. So the formula is a tautology.

Suppose that [\gamma _{1p} \land \cdots \land \gamma _{np}] \to \phi _p is a tautology. Let v be a truth assignment such that \overline (v)([\gamma _{1p} \land \cdots \land \gamma _{np}]) = T. If there is no such assignment, then the claim holds vacuosly. We know that \overline (v)(\phi _p) = T by definiton of tautology. Thus, every assignment that makes the formulas in \Gamma _p true also makes \phi _p true. Thus, \phi _p is a propositional consequence of \Gamma _p.
If \Gamma is a finite set of \mathcal {L}-formulas, \phi is an \mathcal {L}-formula, and \phi is a propositional consequence of \Gamma , then (\Gamma , \phi ) is a rule of inference of type (PC).

Suppose that the variable x is not free in the formula \psi . Then the following are rules of type (QR):
(\{ \psi \to \phi \}, \psi (\forall x \phi ))
(\{ \phi \to \psi \}, (\exists x \phi ) \to \psi )

We will prove the validity of the equality axioms (E1), (E2), and (E3). Let \mathcal {U} be any struture and s any assignment function.
(E1)
We want to show that \mathcal {U} \vDash ((\forall x)(x = x))[s].
By definition, \mathcal {U} \vDash ((\forall x)(x = x))[s] if and only if \mathcal {U} \vDash ((\forall x)(x = x))[s[a/x]] for each a \in \mathcal {U}. Thus, we want to show that \overline {s}'(x) = \overline {s}'(x) for each a \in \mathcal {U} where s' = [s[a/x]]. Well, {s'(x) = s'(x)} for each a in \mathcal {U} because a = a for any a \in \mathcal {U}. Thus, (E1) is valid

(E2)
We want to show that \mathcal {U} \vDash ((x_1 = y_1) \land \cdots \land (x_n = y_n) \to (f(x_1, \cdots , x_n) = f(y_1, \cdots , y_n)))(s).
Suppose s(x_1) = s(y_1), \cdots , s(x_n) = s(y_n). We want to show that \overline {s}(f(x_1, \cdots , x_n)) = \overline {s}(f(y_1, \cdots , y_n)). By the definition of term assignment, f(\overline {s}(x_1), \cdots , \overline {s}(x_n)) = f^{\mathcal {U}}(\overline {s}(y_1), \cdots , \overline {s}(y_n)). Because \overline {s}(x_i) = s(x_i) = s(y_i) = \overline {s}(y_i) and f^{\mathcal {U}} is a function, this is true. Thus, (E2) is valid.

(E3)
We want to show that \mathcal {U} \vDash ((x_1 = y_1) \land \cdots \land (x_n = y_n) \to (R(x_1, \cdots , x_n) = R(y_1, \cdots , y_n)))(s).
Suppose \mathcal {U} \vDash (x_1 = y_1) \land \cdots \land (x_n = y_n) (s). Then, s(x_1) = s(y_1), \cdots , s(x_n) = s(y_n). We want to show that \mathcal {U} \vDash (R(x_1, \cdots , x_n) = R(y_1, \cdots , y_n)). By definition, this translates to showing \overline {s}(R(x_1, \cdots , x_n)) = \overline {s}(R(y_1, \cdots , y_n)). By definition of term assignment, this is equivalent to saying R^{\mathcal {U}}(\overline {s}(x_1), \cdots , \overline {s}(x_n)) = R^{\mathcal {U}}(\overline {s}(y_1), \cdots , \overline {s}(y_n)). Because \overline {s}(x_i) = s(x_i) = s(y_i) = \overline {s}(y_i) and R^{\mathcal {U}} is a relation, this is true. Thus, (E3) is valid.

We prove that the quantifier axioms (Q1) and (Q2) are valid. Let \mathcal {U} be any structure and s any assignment function. Suppose t is substitutable for x in \phi .
(Q1) We want to show that \mathcal {U} \vDash (\forall x \phi ) \to \phi ^{x}_{t} [s], if t is substitutable for x in \phi .
If the antecedent is false, we are done. So suppose \mathcal {U} \vDash (\forall x \phi )[s], which means \mathcal {U} \vDash (\phi )[s[a/x]] for every a \in \mathcal {U}.
We want to show that \mathcal {U} \vDash \phi ^{x}_{t}[s]. Well, we know \mathcal {U} \vDash (\phi )[s[\overline {s}(t)/x]] because \overline {s} maps the term t to some element in \mathcal {U}. Thus, \mathcal {U} \vDash \phi ^{x}_{t}[s]. It is shown later that \phi (s[\overline {s}(t)/x]) and \phi ^{x}_{t}[s] are equivalent.

(Q2) We want to show that \mathcal {U} \vDash \phi ^{x}_{t} \to (\exists x \phi )[s].
Suppose that \mathcal {U} \vDash \phi ^{x}_{t}[s]. We want to show that \mathcal {U} \vDash (\exists x \phi )[s]. By definition this means, \mathcal {U} \vDash \phi (s[a/x]) for some a \in \mathcal {U}. Well we know \mathcal {U} \vDash \phi (s[\overline {s}(t)/x]) because \overline {s} maps the term t to some element in \mathcal {U}. Thus, \mathcal {U} \vDash \phi (s[a/x]).

Fix sets of \mathcal {L}-formulas \Sigma and \Lambda and a collection of rules of inference. The set T = \{ \phi | \Sigma \vdash \phi \} is the smallest set C such that
\Sigma \subset C
\Lambda \subset C
If (\Gamma , \theta ) is a rule of inference and \Gamma \subset C, then \theta \in C

We begin by proving the three properties for T.
We want to show that \Sigma \subset T. It is sufficient to show that each \sigma \in \Sigma is in T. Well, for each \sigma \in \Sigma we know that \Sigma \vdash \sigma because we can write the one line deduction with just \sigma . Thus, \sigma \in \Sigma is in T.

We want to show that \Lambda \subset T. It is sufficient to show that each \lambda \in \Lambda is in T. Well, for each \lambda in \Lambda we know that \Sigma \vdash \lambda because we can write the one line deduction with just \lambda . Thus. \lambda in \Lambda is in T.

Suppose that (\Gamma , \theta ) is a rule of inference and that \Gamma \subset T. We want to show that \theta \in T. It is sufficient to create a deduction from \Sigma that ends with \theta . By our supposition that \Gamma \subset T, we know that each \gamma \in T. Thus, \Sigma \vdash \gamma for each \gamma . Consider the deduction that is the concatenation of all the deductions ending in a \gamma . From this deduction, we can add the line \theta because \Gamma is a subset of the preceding lines. Thus, we have constructed a deduction from \Sigma to \theta .

Now, we want to show that T is the smallest such set that satisfies the aforementioned properties. Consider a set C that satisfies the three properties. It is sufficient to show that T \subset C by demonstrating that all \phi \in T are also in C. Let \phi \in T. There must be deduction from \Sigma to \phi . Suppose that the last line \phi is justified because it is a logical or non-logical axiom. Then, \phi is in C by definition. Now suppose that \phi is justified by a rule of inference. Then, there is a (\Gamma , \phi ) such that each \gamma appears deduction. Thus, by straightforward induction we get each \gamma is in C. Thus, by the third property, \phi is in C.

Suppose that u is a term, x is a variable, and t is a term. Suppose that s : Vars \to A is a variable assignment function and that s' = s[x|\overline {s}(t)]. Then \overline {s}(u^{x}_{t}) = \overline {s^{'}}(u).

Suppose that \phi is an L-formula, x is a variable, t is a term, and t is substitutable for x in \phi . Suppose that s : Vars \ to A is a variable assignment function and that s' = s[x|\overline {s}(t)]. Then U \vDash \phi ^{x}_{t}[s] if and only if U \vDash \phi [s'].
\Sigma \vdash \theta if and only if \Sigma \vdash \forall x. \theta
Suppose that \Sigma \vdash \theta . We can produce a deduction for \forall \theta by adding an application of LEM, QR, and modus ponens to the deduction of \theta .
Suppose that \Sigma \vdash \forall x. \theta . We only need to add an application of Q1 to the deduction of \forall x. \theta to produce a deduction of \theta .

Suppose that \Sigma \vdash \theta . Then if \Sigma ' is formed by taking any \sigma \in \Sigma and adding or deleting a universal quantifier whose scope is the entire formula, \Sigma ' \vdash \theta .
This lemma follows immediately from the preceding lemma.
Suppose that \theta is a sentence and \Sigma is a set of formulas. Then \Sigma \cup \theta \vdash \theta if and only if \Sigma \vdash (\theta \to \phi )
